article.p: Why BCHS? Because the open Internet is damn inhospitable.

section.p: OpenBSD. Documentation. Security. Reliable six-month releases. It takes the guess-work out of your environment.
Resources: man pages, FAQ, Absolute OpenBSD.
C is a straightforward, non-mustachioed language. It has full access to the kernel's system calls and a massive set of development tools.
Resources: The C Programming Language, gcc-local(1).
OpenBSD's home-grown web server. If you need more features for your web application, start rethinking.
SQLite is a self-contained, embeddable, zero-configuration database. And it's bundled with stock OpenBSD.
Resources: API reference (or convert to manpages).

article.p: Install, fire up the web server, and get to work. What next? Consider your tools.
article.aside: BCHS is a stable, developer-oriented set of tools for handling data in a hostile environment. Get used to minimalism and security: statically-compiled, privilege-separated binaries in file-system jails. Use powerful system tools directly instead of depending on PHP to hold your hand. And most of all, forget your LAMP instincts to desperately search Google and StackExchange for every parameter: man pages are your new best friend.
